title: Welcome!
text:
Session Brief



This one-day in-person workshop is designed for those with a basic working knowledge of NVivo for qualitative research projects. It is designed to introduce you to more advanced features and the flexible ways these can be used for qualitative analysis. It is designed as a follow-on from the “Introduction to Qualitative Analysis Projects in NVivo”, but is open to everyone regardless of whether they attended that session.
Students will learn how to use some more advanced features of NVivo:

coding workflows, tip and tricks
using static and dynamic sets
different types of queries
framework matrices

We will use some curated open access qualitative data (the Qualitative Election Study of Britain). However, there is an opportunity to discuss how to use NVivo to manage your own project.

title: About
text:
These online NVivo Guidance and Workshop pages for the Scottish Graduate School of Social Science are produced by:

Dr Kathryn Fredricks
Dr Katherine Keenan
Alasdair B R Stewart

With additional material from:

Dr Rachel Shanks

These pages are ‘living documents’ and will incrementally be updated over time.

title: Primers on qualitative data and analysis
text: If you have never had formal masters-level training in qualitative enquiry, we recommend you follow some introductory material before you atten the NVivo workshops. This will help you get the most out of the day.

title: Primers on qualitative data and analysis
section: What is qualitative enquiry and data?
text:
What is qualitative enquiry and data?
Engage with one or all of the following:

The Discipline and Practice of Qualitative Research which is Chapter 1 in Denzin and Lincoln, eds. (2018) The SAGE Handbook of Qualitative Research. 5th ed. London: SAGE Publications.
Introduction to qualitative research methods - Part 1 by Bhangu, Provost, and Caduff (2023) in Perspectives in Clinical Research 14(1) pp.39-42
Qualitative research the basics YouTube video by Degree Doctor (Dr Elizabeth Yardley)

title: Primers on qualitative data and analysis
text:
What is thematic analysis?
Thematic analysis is a commonly used method within qualitative analysis, suitable for using with software like NVivo.
Papers:

Braun, Virginia, and Victoria Clarke (2006) ‘Using Thematic Analysis in Psychology’. Qualitative Research in Psychology 3(2):77–101. doi: 10.1191/1478088706qp063oa.
Braun, Virginia, and Victoria Clarke (2019) ‘Reflecting on Reflexive Thematic Analysis’. Qualitative Research in Sport, Exercise and Health 11(4):589–97. doi: 10.1080/2159676X.2019.1628806.
Byrne, David. (2022) ‘A Worked Example of Braun and Clarke’s Approach to Reflexive Thematic Analysis’. Quality & Quantity 56(3):1391–1412. doi: 10.1007/s11135-021-01182-y.
Kiger, Michelle E., and Lara Varpio. (2020) ‘Thematic Analysis of Qualitative Data: AMEE Guide No. 131’. Medical Teacher 42(8):846–54. doi: 10.1080/0142159X.2020.1755030.

YouTube:

Thematic analysis in qualitative research by Degree Doctor (Dr Elizabeth Yardley)

title: Primers on qualitative data and analysis
text:
What is coding?

An Introduction to Codes and Coding which is Chapter 1 in Saldaña (2013) The Coding Manual for Qualitative Researchers. 2nd ed. London: Sage Publications Ltd.

title: Resources
text: If you are new to qualitative enquiry, please see the Primers page for recommended introduction materials.

title: Resources
text:
Recommended Reading

Qualitative Analysis Software
The best texts on using software for qualitative analysis:

Jackson, Kristi, and Pat Bazeley. (2019) Qualitative Data Analysis with NVivo. 3rd ed. Thousand Oaks, CA: SAGE Publications Ltd.

PDF for Chapter 1 - ‘Where to begin?’
Click by click instructions accompanying the book.

Bazeley, Pat. (2017) ‘Using Qualitative Data Analysis Software (QDAS) to Assist Data Analyses’. Pp. 1–18 in Handbook of Research Methods in Health Social Sciences, edited by P. Liamputtong. Singapore: Springer.

Open access copy.




Qualitative Analysis
Also useful as a basis for understanding qualitative analysis, coding, and writing up more generally:

Bazeley, Pat. 2020. Qualitative Data Analysis: Practical Strategies. 2nd ed. London: SAGE Pubications.

Hard-copies available in most university libraries.

Saldaña, Johnny. (2013) The Coding Manual for Qualitative Researchers. 2nd ed. London: Sage Publications Ltd.

An Introduction to Codes and Coding PDF of Chapter 1.




NVivo Examples

Byrne, David. (2022) ‘A Worked Example of Braun and Clarke’s Approach to Reflexive Thematic Analysis’. Quality & Quantity 56(3):1391–1412. doi: 10.1007/s11135-021-01182-y.
Hutchison, Andrew John, Lynne Halley Johnston, and Jeff David Breckon. (2010) ‘Using QSR‐NVivo to Facilitate the Development of a Grounded Theory Project: An Account of a Worked Example’. International Journal of Social Research Methodology 13(4):283–302. doi: 10.1080/13645570902996301.

title: Qualitative Analysis Projects with NVivo
text:
Session Brief



This one-day in-person workshop is designed for those with a basic working knowledge of NVivo for qualitative research projects. It is designed to introduce you to more advanced features and the flexible ways these can be used for qualitative analysis. It is designed as a follow-on from the “Introduction to Qualitative Analysis Projects in NVivo”, but is open to everyone regardless of whether they attended that session.
Students will learn how to use some more advanced features of NVivo:

title: Project File
text: testing

title: Welcome!
text:
Session Aims

🧑‍🎓 NVivo 201 - Additive Analysis
…


🤔 Problem-based approach
Linking analysis aims with NVivo features conceptual … and demonstration experimentation and discussion

Important - please use the experimentation and discussion to raise any questions re own project and plans



🗺️ Organising and navigating
…


🧶 Layering and weaving
…
(distance between steps - why may want to do 1 thing that can reuse again and again)


🧟 Slaying QDAS zombies
…


🤢 It’s not you, it’s NVivo!
NVivo is powerful and without a doubt better than analogue paper and pen analysis – or worse, copying and pasting chunks of text into multiple Word/Excel files – but it remains far from perfect. It is needlessly bloated and clunky, and historically had a reputation for regularly crashing.
The unintuitive design and labyrinthine steps required for some tasks – never mind the joys of trying to recall them each time when first starting – gives the false impression that it is all overly-complex. It might not seem it now, but with perseverance the pieces start fitting together, and the initial overwhelm will dissipate into mild frustrations.
To Lumivero’s credit, the rate at which NVivo crashes has vastly reduced and is no longer a daily occurrence. However, it can still throw up the occasional unexpected error, freeze and lock-up, or decide to crash and die completely. This is most often ‘NVivo-error’ not ‘user-error’ – there was not anything wrong in how you set up your project or actions you were doing, it’s just NVivo being NVivo.
